newsitem.title: CANADA: Wal-Mart Canada starts union bargaining.
newsitem.headline: Wal-Mart Canada starts union bargaining.

text.p: The Canadian unit of Wal-Mart Stores Inc said on Wednesday it began bargaining with union members at the first-ever unionized store for the world's largest retailer.
Wal-Mart Canada Inc and the United Steelworkers of America began negotiations for a contract at its Windsor, Ontario, outlet on March 17 and plan to continue on April 29, 30 and May 12, 13.

Wal-Mart Canada, which quickly became Canada's largest discount chain since arriving in 1994, is wholly owned by the Bentonville, Ark.-based retailer. Windsor is on the Canada-U.S. border near Detroit.

Spokesman Ed Gould declined to disclose any of the issues on the table. "We're continuing to bargain in good faith at the table to get a collective agreement, and that is where we're going to do the negotiations."
Wal-Mart Canada also reiterated it will appeal a mid-February decision by the Ontario Labor Relations Board to certify the union.
Gould said the retailers will file a notice of application at a division of Ontario's court.
"We've said from the start that we felt that Wal-Mart acted fairly and that the decision did not reflect the true wishes of our people and our appeal will be based on those two levels," Gould said.
Wal-Mart Canada said the appeal will be heard by a panel of Ontario's Divisional Court within three to six months.
The ruling came despite a May 10, 1996 vote by Windsor store employees rejecting a union drive by 151-43.

The tribunal, which administers labor laws in Canada's most populous province, ruled Wal-Mart executives used unfair labor practices by refusing to tell employees whether they would shut the store if it became unionized.
